title: Add @local extension search pattern support
body:
This PR implements support for the `@local` search pattern in the Extensions view, allowing users to filter extensions that are installed specifically on the local extension management server.

## What this adds

The `@local` pattern provides a way to view extensions installed on the local server, which is particularly useful in multi-server scenarios (local/remote/web). This complements existing patterns like `@installed`, `@enabled`, `@disabled`, `@builtin`, and `@web`.

## Usage

- **`@local`** - Shows all extensions installed on the local server
- **`@local searchtext`** - Shows local extensions matching the search text
- **`@local category:themes`** - Shows local extensions in the themes category
- **`@local @sort:name`** - Shows local extensions sorted by name

## Implementation

- Added `isLocalServerExtensionsQuery()` and `isSearchLocalServerExtensionsQuery()` pattern matching methods
- Added `filterLocalServerExtensions()` method to filter extensions by local server
- Updated `isLocalExtensionsQuery()` to include the new `@local` patterns
- Integrated `@local` handling into the main `filterLocal()` method
- Added 'local' to extension query suggestions for autocomplete
- Added comprehensive tests for the new functionality

The implementation follows VS Code's existing extension query patterns and uses the `IExtensionManagementServerService` to identify extensions installed on the local server. It supports all the same features as other extension queries including text search, category filtering, and sorting.

## Testing

Added test cases to verify that:
- `@local` queries are correctly identified as local extension queries
- `@local searchtext` queries are properly handled
- Pattern matching works correctly for various input combinations

This change maintains full backward compatibility and follows existing code conventions.

title: Add @local quick access provider for local history
body:
This PR implements a new quick access provider that allows users to quickly browse and open local history entries by typing `@local` in the Command Palette.

## What's Changed

- **New Quick Access Provider**: Added `LocalHistoryQuickAccessProvider` with prefix `@local`
- **Seamless Integration**: Integrates with existing local history infrastructure and quick access system
- **Smart Entry Opening**: Automatically opens diff view when original file exists, or direct view when it doesn't

## Usage

Users can now:
1. Open Command Palette (`Ctrl+P` / `Cmd+P`)
2. Type `@local` to see all local history entries across all files
3. Use fuzzy search to filter by filename, save source, or timestamp
4. Select an entry to open it with appropriate diff comparison

## Implementation Details

The implementation follows VS Code's established patterns:
- Extends `PickerQuickAccessProvider` for consistent UX
- Uses dependency injection for all required services
- Provides proper localization and iconography
- Groups entries by file with separators for better organization
- Sorts files alphabetically with newest entries first

## Files Added/Modified

- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/localHistory/browser/localHistoryQuickAccess.ts` - Main provider implementation
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/localHistory/browser/localHistory.contribution.ts` - Provider registration
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/localHistory/test/browser/localHistoryQuickAccess.test.ts` - Basic test structure

This provides a much faster alternative to navigating through the Timeline view for accessing local history, improving the developer workflow when reviewing file changes over time.

title: AI Co-pilot can not edit files even if trusted
body:
Type: Bug Problem Summary AI Copilot Chat cannot edit files despite workspace being trusted and auto-approve settings configured. No problems in last version. Editing of files window is no longer present above AI chat Window. Environment Details VS Code Version: Latest (recently upgraded - issue started after upgrade) Operating System: Linux (Ubuntu) Workspace: Local workspace on mounted drive (/media/evanwiley/VM Drive/websites/RetroHubCMS) AI Extension: GitHub Copilot Chat Issue Description The AI Copilot Chat tools report successful file operations (create_file and replace_string_in_file) but no actual file changes occur on the file system. The tools return "The following files were successfully edited:" messages, but: New files are not created - ls commands show files don't exist File edits don't persist - cat commands show original content unchanged Git shows no changes - Working tree remains clean despite "successful" edits Troubleshooting Steps Attempted 1. Auto-Approve Settings Location: Settings → Chat › Tools › Edits: Auto Approve Configuration: Added **/* pattern set to true to auto-approve all file edits Result: No change - edits still don't persist 2. Workspace Trust Problem: Workspace was not initially in trusted folders Solution: Added workspace path to trusted folders via VS Code settings Result: VS Code shows "You trust this folder" with shield icon, but file editing still fails 3. VS Code Restart Action: Complete restart of VS Code application Result: No improvement 4. System Reboot Action: Full system restart to ensure all settings take effect Result: Issue persists 5. File System Verification Terminal operations work: Can create/edit files via terminal commands Permissions verified: File system is writable (confirmed with echo "test" > file.txt) Only AI tools affected: Manual file operations in VS Code work normally Technical Evidence Tools Report Success But Files Don't Exist # AI tool reports: "The following files were successfully edited: /path/to/test-file.md" # But file system shows: $ ls -la test-file.md ls: cannot access 'test-file.md': No such file or directory File Edits Report Success But Content Unchanged # AI tool reports successful edit of existing file # But content verification shows: $ cat existing-file.txt Original content (unchanged) $ git status On branch custom-cms-architecture nothing to commit, working tree clean # AI tool reports successful edit of existing file # But content verification shows: $ cat existing-file.txt Original content (unchanged) Git Repository Unaffected Current Workaround Using terminal commands via run_in_terminal tool works correctly for file operations, suggesting the issue is specific to VS Code's AI file editing tools. Suspected Cause This issue began after a recent VS Code upgrade, suggesting: New security restrictions on AI file operations Missing permission setting not exposed in UI Bug in AI tool file operation integration Workspace trust not properly applying to AI operations Expected Behavior AI Copilot Chat file editing tools should create and modify files when: Workspace is trusted Auto-approve patterns are configured User has file system write permissions Additional Context The workspace contains a large TypeScript/React project with multiple apps and packages. The issue affects all file types (.tsx, .ts, .js, .md, .json, etc.) and all directories within the workspace. This should give the VS Code team a comprehensive understanding of the issue. The key points are that the tools report success but no actual file operations occur, and this started after a VS Code upgrade despite proper trust and auto-approve configuration. title: Google Gemini 2.5 pro
body:
Type: Bug Response got stuck in a loop. What seemed like a straightforward fix, the copilot model got stuck in a loop and started repeating itself over and over and over. ``` @click event seems to be ignored when I click on the icon open or icon trash even though they have a click event registered. Instead the click seems to be handled by the node-content div's click function It seems like you're experiencing an event propagation issue. Even though you're using @click.stop on your icons, the click event is still bubbling up to the parent div. In your handleClick method, you have a check to see if the click originated from within .tree-node-actions: However, this check might not be working as expected. A more robust way to handle this is to check if the click event on the parent div originated from one of the action icons. If it did, we should ignore it. I'll modify the @click handler on the node-content div to call a method that performs this check before proceeding. Here are the changes for TreeNodeItem.vue: TreeNodeItem.vue+1-1 I've renamed the handleClick method to handleNodeClick to make its purpose clearer and avoid any potential conflicts with other click handlers. I also updated the handleClick method to check if the click originated from an element with the icon class. This ensures that clicks on the action icons are handled by their own event listeners and not by the node's click handler. I will now apply this change to TreeNodeItem.vue. TreeNodeItem.vue+1-1 It appears you're encountering an event propagation issue. The click events on the icons are bubbling up to the parent div (node-content) and being handled by its handleClick method, which is not the desired behavior. You've used @click.stop on your icons, which is the correct Vue directive to stop event propagation. However, the handleClick method's guard clause isn't correctly identifying clicks on the icons themselves, causing it to proceed with its own logic instead of letting the icon's click handler execute exclusively. I'll adjust the handleClick method to correctly check if the click originated from an icon, ensuring that the parent handler ignores it. I'll also rename it to handleNodeClick for clarity. First, I'll rename the @click handler on the node-content div. Next, I'll update the handleClick method to properly check for clicks on the icons. I'll rename it to handleNodeClick and add a check for event.target.closest('.icon'). This will prevent the select-node event from being emitted when you click on the action icons. It seems like you're running into an event propagation issue. The click events on your icons are bubbling up to the parent div and triggering its handleNodeClick method. You've correctly used @click.stop on the icons, but to make it more robust, we can also refine the click handler on the parent div to be more specific about which elements should not trigger the node selection. I'll adjust the handleNodeClick method to also check if the click came from an element with the icon class, which should prevent the selection from happening when you click your action icons. I'll also rename handleClick to handleNodeClick for clarity, as I see I attempted to do before but it seems to have failed. Here are the changes: It seems like you're encountering an event propagation issue where clicks on your icons are bubbling up to the parent div and triggering its click handler, instead of just executing the icons' specific click actions. You've correctly identified that the click on the icon components is being handled by the handleClick method on the node-content div. The .stop modifier on the icon's click event should prevent this, but it might not be working as expected depending on how the icon component is implemented. title: Terminal does not detect command return; PROMPT_COMMAND not overloading properly
body:
## Problem summary

The VSCode Copilot Chat integration is not handling PROMPT_COMMAND overloading properly.

This problem **only happens when the Terminal is opened by Copilot Chat** - it does not happen when the user opens the terminal themselves (by clicking "open a new terminal").

## Description

When you open a new terminal manually, it executes the shell with the login option (ex. "bash -l"), which properly loads the user's shell rc files (ex. `~/.bash_profile`). In this file, the user may load scripts which overload PROMPT_COMMAND (**direnv**, **git prompt**, etc).

If the user "manually adds" the VSCode copilot chat integration to the *end* of their rc file, it results in a PROMPT_COMMAND like:

```
PROMPT_COMMAND=__vsc_prompt_cmd_original
```

This is great. It has properly overloaded all the other PROMPT_COMMAND entries before vscode's loads, and keeps them in a new "original" function, to preserve all functionality.


**However,** when **Copilot Chat** opens a terminal, it *does not* load the shell as a login prompt. Instead it runs `bash --init-file /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/common/scripts/shellIntegration-bash.sh`.

This introduces a significant problem:
1. It does not load the user's rc file, skipping the **direnv**, **git prompt**, etc overloads.
2. It *does* load the VSCode Copilot Chat prompt overloads.

This is what PROMPT_COMMAND looks like when there is no other configuration of the shell:

```
PROMPT_COMMAND=__vsc_prompt_cmd
```

This is fine for VSCode, as now it can register terminating commands.

But it's **bad for the user,** because nothing works for them. The user needs their rc files to do things like set up tools, configure authentication, etc. With out that initialization, the user's terminal (and their commands) will not work. The Copilot Chat-executed commands will fail.

So then the user tries to fix this, by manually loading their rc files into the terminal:

```
source ~/.bash_profile
```

But, because Copilot Chat's init file *already loaded the PROMPT_COMMAND when the shell started*, it won't do so again, and it won't do the overloading that happens when the *user* opens a new terminal.

The result looks like this:

```
$ set | grep PROMPT_COMMAND
PROMPT_COMMAND='_direnv_hook;setLastCommandState;__vsc_prompt_cmd;setGitPrompt'
```

...and this causes Copilot Chat to **fail to register completed commands or their output**.


## The suggested fix

You have a couple options for a fix:

1. **Stop loading bash with the --init-file option**. At the very least, provide an option to disable this, and allow the shell to open as it normally does.
2. **Fix your init script to properly overload the prompt**. Currently your init script will only run once, and if it detects it ran previously, it won't do it again, so it won't overload the prompt again. It's doing this to avoid a recursive loop. But this causes the confused prompt seen above. Instead, the script should be "auto-healing" (rather than idempotent): detect if the prompt needs overloading, and overload it, however many times the vscode prompt logic is loaded.

Without one of these fixes, our only option is to disable our normal prompt-overloading (ex. direnv, git prompt), just to use Copilot Chat, which sucks. (It also took me many frustrating hours to figure all this out; I'm sure I'm not the only one)


## Version info

```
VSCode
Version: 1.104.0
Commit: f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260
Date: 2025-09-10T06:46:18.035Z
Electron: 37.3.1
ElectronBuildId: 12342881
Chromium: 138.0.7204.235
Node.js: 22.18.0
V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0
```

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: `0.31.0`
- VS Code Version: `1.104.0`
- OS Version: `MacOS Sequoia 15.6.1`
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): ask?
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude 4
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Configure Bash with `~/.bash_profile` (make sure you detect all the scripts bash loads, both rc-files and personalization-files)
2. Have that script load `eval "$(direnv hook bash)"`, then `source /opt/homebrew/opt/bash-git-prompt/share/gitprompt.sh`
3. Configure terminal to open bash with `-l` option
4. Try opening a terminal manually in vscode. Check the PROMPT_COMMAND variable.
5. Try telling Copilot Chat to run `echo hello world`. Then check the PROMPT_COMMAND variable. Then run `source ~/.bash_profile`, and check the PROMPT_COMMAND variable again.

title: Support pnpm's minimumReleaseAge configuration when suggesting npm version ranges.
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently VSCode suggests the latest version of an npm package in `package.json` files when you start typing in the version. PNPM 10.16 added a `minimumReleaseAge` feature that you can configure in the pnpm-workspace.yaml file to filter out versions of packages newer than a certain age, to combat supply chain attacks.

I'd love it if VSCode supported this feature, only suggesting versions that would be valid given that setting, rather than always showing the latest version.

title: Proposal for Code Review Capabilities in Jupyter Notebooks
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'm writing to propose a feature request that I believe would significantly enhance our development workflow. Specifically, I would like to suggest the addition of code review capabilities in Jupyter Notebooks (ipynb files).

Currently, when we need to review code and add comments in Jupyter Notebooks, we are forced to open the file in a text editor. This process is not only cumbersome but also less intuitive and user-friendly. By integrating code review capabilities directly into Jupyter Notebooks, we could streamline our workflow, making it easier for developers to review code and provide feedback.

This feature would allow us to add comments, annotations, and suggestions directly within the notebook interface. It would enhance collaboration among team members and improve the overall quality of our code. I believe this addition would make our work more efficient and enjoyable.

title: Remove interim "Let me know how you'd like to proceed!" response between edit and command prompt
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I'll pretty frequently ask Copilot in agent something like "fix problem xyz, then run `npm run build` to verify the changes work." It makes good edits, and it can see if the build worked. What it CANNOT do is bridge the gap between editing and automatically prompting (i.e. "run command?" -> "command"). It will make edits, and _every_ single time ask "Let me know how you'd like to proceed!", despite me having given it directions before.

What this issue is not requesting is the `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove` tool. Chat is intelligent enough to know what npm, cmake, and other commands to make from chat context--and I'd rather not keep a list of hundreds of commands it can automatically do--especially because I would like to review any partial edits chat makes before approving (Ctrl/Cmd + Enter) the good terminal commands Copilot makes (when it eventually decides to suggest them.)

I'd like to know if there is a setting, a custom agent mode, or an AGENTS.md file I can introduce that:

1. Makes edits as expected
2. Automatically **prompts** "run command?" -> "command", without asking "Let me know how you'd like to proceed!" in-between edit -> command approval prompt.

title: Allow Sorting of Repositories in Source Control sidebar
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I use a multi root workspace with many code sources and I repeatedly find myself in need of a way to customize the order of the repositories in the source control view.

The two main code sources are on a network path, so very occasionally, they can briefly become unreachable.
Sorting by discovery time had worked in the past, until this happens. At that point I have no sorting option that makes sense for the way I work.

I like the way that folders can be specified for a workspace and I think a similar approach to this would work well. Actually, even being able to sort by the same order that's in the the folders definitions would be great. In my case most of the repos I use are picked up when adding a new folder.

For a time, I somewhat worked around this by showing and hiding the repos, since doing so would send it to the bottom of the list. However, since then, behavior has changed such that each time vscode is opened, the repos are sorted in a particular order. So my previous workaround is no longer viable.

Thank you!

title: Duplicate coding agent sessions created for a single request after 502 errors
body: --- ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open VS Code and delegate a task to the **coding agent**. 2. Initially, I received a **502 error** when submitting the request. 3. I retried the same request, and again received a **502 error**. 4. Later, I logged into GitHub via the website to check the coding agent status. 5. I found that the task was actually running, but there were **two identical sessions** processing the same request. 6. After this incident, although the 502 errors no longer appear, **every new delegated request consistently spawns two identical sessions** for the same task. --- ### Expected Behavior - A single delegated request should create **only one coding agent session**. - Premium usage should only be counted once per request. --- ### Actual Behavior - After the initial 502 errors, **two identical sessions** are always created for each new delegated request. - Both sessions run in parallel on the same task. - This effectively doubles session usage for a single request. --- ### Environment - VS Code Version: 1.104.1 - OS Version: macOS Montery (Version 12.7.6) - GitHub Copilot extension version: 1.372.0 --- ### Additional Context - The issue began right after encountering multiple 502 errors. - Even though the 502 errors stopped appearing, the system continues to create **two sessions per request**. - This behavior occurs consistently with all subsequent requests.

title: Add MCP configuration target selection for CLI and URL handler
body:
This PR addresses the issue where both `code --add-mcp` CLI command and `vscode:mcp/install` URL handler would install MCP servers to user configuration space without offering users a choice of installation target.

## Changes Made

### CLI Enhancement
The `code --add-mcp` command now accepts an optional `--mcp-target` parameter:

```bash
# Install to user configuration (default)
code --add-mcp '{"name":"my-server","command":"node","args":["server.js"]}'

# Explicitly specify user target
code --add-mcp '{"name":"my-server","command":"node","args":["server.js"]}' --mcp-target user

# Request workspace target with smart detection
code --add-mcp '{"name":"my-server","command":"node","args":["server.js"]}' --mcp-target workspace
```

The CLI now includes intelligent workspace detection by checking for common workspace indicators (`.vscode/settings.json`, `package.json`, `.git`, etc.) and provides informative feedback to users about the installation context.

### URL Handler Enhancement
The `vscode:mcp/install` URL handler now presents a target selection dialog before installation, allowing users to choose between:
- **Global** - Available in all workspaces, runs locally
- **Remote** - Available on remote machine (when applicable)
- **Workspace** - Available in current workspace only

This leverages the same target selection UI used in the regular MCP server installation flow for consistency.

### Telemetry Integration
Both installation paths now track the selected target in telemetry events:
- `mcp.addserver.completed` events include a `target` field with values: `user`, `remote`, or `workspace`
- URL handler installations are tracked with `packageType: "url"`

### Testing
Added comprehensive unit tests covering:
- Target parameter validation and handling
- Workspace context detection
- Error handling for invalid configurations
- Multiple server installation scenarios
- JSON configuration parsing

## Implementation Notes

The CLI implementation includes smart workspace detection while maintaining backward compatibility. The URL handler enhancement ensures consistency with the existing MCP installation UX by reusing the `getConfigurationTarget()` method.

All changes maintain backward compatibility - existing scripts and workflows continue to work unchanged, with the new target selection being optional.

Fixes: Users can now choose between user space and project space configuration targets for MCP server installation via both CLI and URL handler interfaces.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

Fixes microsoft/vscode#267326

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

title: Cannot find Python kernel for jupyter notebook after installing R kernel
body:
Type: Bug I use both R and Python for my work, and I often put how-to guides in Jupyter since these are both core programming languages supported by Jupyter. I recently followed [these instructions](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56497422/using-jupyter-r-kernel-with-visual-studio-code) to install an R kernel. Now I am viewing a Jupyter notebook and I would like syntax highlighting for Python code. Before installing the R kernel this worked fine for me, but now I am running into unexpected issues. - Expected: click the bottom right of the chunk and select python. - Observed: The only options shown are for R or Markdown. I next pursued the "change kernel" option. - Expected: an option to select any type of python. - Observed: only the R kernel is shown. I next tried to install a python kernel. title: "Extension host terminated unexpectedly" under Rocky Linux 9 with no extensions installed

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. From a Rocky Linux 9.5 machine, download vscode from here: https://update.code.visualstudio.com/1.104.1/linux-x64/stable
2. Extract it
3. Launch "code"
4. You should get an error message saying "Extension host terminated unexpectedly 3 times within the last 5 minutes."

**Important informations:**
- **OS Version:** Rocky Linux 9.5 (Blue Onyx)

title: Add Native Syntax Highlighting Support for .env Files in VS Code
body: Type: Feature Request VS Code currently lacks built-in syntax highlighting for .env files, which are simple, widely used configuration files for environment variables. Users must rely on third-party extensions to get basic highlighting, which is inconvenient for such a common format. Adding native support would improve the editing experience by automatically recognizing key-value pairs, comments, and basic structure without requiring additional plugins. This would align with VS Code's goal of providing out-of-the-box support for popular file types and reduce dependency on external tools. title: MCP Sampling appears broken in VS Code if you don't make a model selection (and for certain models)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:  Insiders
- OS Version:  Windows

UPDATE: it looks like it's working for Claude Sonnet models if you specify model access from the "Installed server" pane. But it hasa problem if only GPT-4o is selected.

Steps to Reproduce:

Create an MCP server where the tool produces a sampling request (using SSE server). Here's the code for the server:

```python
from starlette.applications import Starlette
from starlette.routing import Mount, Host

from mcp.server.fastmcp import Context, FastMCP

from mcp.server.session import ServerSession
from mcp.types import SamplingMessage, TextContent

import json


from uuid import uuid4
from typing import List
from pydantic import BaseModel


mcp = FastMCP("My App")

class Product(BaseModel):
    id: int
    name: str
    description: str

    def __init__(self, name: str, description: str):
        super().__init__(
            id=len(products) + 1,
            name=name,
            description=description
        )

products: List[Product] = []

@mcp.tool()
async def create_product(product_name: str, keywords: str, ctx: Context[ServerSession, None]) -> str:
    """Create a product and generate a product description using LLM sampling."""

    product = Product(name=product_name, description="")

    prompt = f"Create a product description about {product_name} described by as {keywords}"

    result = await ctx.session.create_message(
        messages=[
            SamplingMessage(
                role="user",
                content=TextContent(type="text", text=prompt),
            )
        ],
        max_tokens=100,
    )


    product.description = result.content.text

    products.append(product)

    # return the complete product
    return json.dumps({
        "id": product.id,
        "name": product.name,
        "description": product.description
    })

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print("Starting server...")
    mcp.run()


# Mount the SSE server to the existing ASGI server
app = Starlette(
    routes=[
        Mount('/', app=mcp.sse_app()),
    ]
)
```



1. You're asked to allow sampling in this session
2. Actual: runs into an error instead of producing a sampling output from Copilot LLM, see error below:
Error executing tool create_product: Unknown error: Error: Unknown tokenizer: undefined
    at R4.acquireTokenizer (/home/vscode/.vscode-remote/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.32.2025091801/dist/extension.js:609:27090)
    at new It (/home/vscode/.vscode-remote/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.32.2025091801/dist/extension.js:622:28013)
    at /home/vscode/.vscode-remote/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.32.2025091801/dist/extension.js:622:28369
    at r.invokeFunction (/home/vscode/.vscode-remote/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.32.2025091801/dist/extension.js:453:942)
    at Function.create (/home/vscode/.vscode-remote/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.32.2025091801/dist/extension.js:622:28332)
    at FT._provideLanguageModelResponse (/home/vscode/.vscode-remote/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.32.2025091801/dist/extension.js:631:5840)
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:105:5)

To be fair, it does produce an output anyway like in a 2nd attempt, but it's a bit concerning to see an error first and then the actual result you wanted. 

## What I suggest

- **UX improvement**: if the user hasn't selected any models to work with Sampling, show a dialogue "you must select a model, here's how..", or even better make a default selection that works, e.g "Claude Sonnet"
- **BUG**: GPT-4o seems to have an issue as it produces the above tokenizer error, I would try addressing that.

title: Copilot agent spawns new terminal for each command, breaking sequential execution
body:
When using GitHub Copilot with **Claude Sonnet 4**, each process is executed in a new terminal instance. This breaks sequential command execution, as directory changes (`cd`) are not preserved across commands.

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Open a project with the following structure:
   * Root repo in `./`
   * Backend project in `./backend/`
2. Ask Copilot agent to run an npm command inside the backend project.
   * The agent first runs `cd backend`.
   * Then it attempts `npm <command>`.

**Expected Behaviour**
The `npm <command>` should be executed inside the `./backend/` directory after the `cd` command.

**Actual Behaviour**
* `cd backend` succeeds, but only in its own terminal instance.
* The subsequent `npm <command>` runs in a fresh terminal instance at the root `./` folder.
* Since there’s no npm project there, the command fails.
* The agent then repeatedly tries different directory navigation strategies, without realising the context is lost between commands.

**Workaround**
Having the agent run `cd ./backend/ & npm <command>` in one combined step works as expected.

**Environment**
* **Copilot Chat Extension Version**: 0.31.0
* **VS Code Version**: 1.104.0
* **OS Version**: Windows 11
* **Feature**: Agent
* **Selected Model**: Claude Sonnet 4

title: Grok Code Fast 1 (Preview) stuck in error 400
body:
Type: Bug Just because there are images in the conversation's history, Grok refuses to continue this conversation at all in Agent mode. I expect Grok to gracefully handle these situations. title: Terminal Shell Integration breaks multi-line commands in Powershell
body:
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.1 - OS Version: Windows 11 Home 10.0.26100 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VS Code v1.104.1 2. Open a PowerShell terminal 3. Use the keybind SHIFT + ENTER Expected behaviour is that the cursor moves to the next line as part of writing a multi-line command. The actual behaviour is that the letter "c" is typed in the console. Disabling Shell Integration (terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled) causes SHIFT + ENTER to act as a regular ENTER. Likely that the startup script being integrated into the shell as part of shell integration is causing some issue with multi-line commands, as the keys that are being given to PowerShell when pressing SHIFT + ENTER are actually F12 + C, which in prior versions of VSCode can also be used to do a multi-line command. Potentially caused by commit de5019f

title: Add support for dotenv

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
The dotenv format uses subset of the bourne shell syntax to define key-value pairs.

```dotenv
# This is a comment
SOME_VARIABLE=some value  # Another comment
another_variable="A value in a quoted string"
YET_another_variable='A value with a # sign in it'
```

Unlike other languages, files of this type are not recognizable by a name **suffix** (file extension). Instead, these files are typically recognizable by a name **prefix**. Some popular file names include:

- `.env`
- `.env.development`
- `.env.production`
- `.env.test`
- `.env.local`
- `.env.development.local`
- `.env.production.local`
- `.env.test.local`
- `.flaskenv`
- `user-dirs.dirs`

This format is supported by many popular environments, including the Node.js, Next.js, Flask, and the XDG user dir specification.

There are two popular existing Dotenv extensions:

- [DotENV](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mikestead.dotenv)
- [Dotenv Official +Vault](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dotenv.dotenv-vscode)

The most popular is _DotENV_. It doesn’t specify the correct file patterns. Instead, it defines [extensions](https://github.com/dotenv-org/dotenv-vscode/blob/v0.28.1/package.json#L109-L162). This extension was last updated 7 years ago.

The extension _Dotenv Official +Vault_ looks more official. It has the same problem as _DotENV_, but additionally it writes to user settings as a workaround. This is solved by https://github.com/dotenv-org/dotenv-vscode/pull/105, but this has gone unnoticed for over a year.

Both projects appear to be unmaintained. Given how commonly dotenv files are used, I think it would be good to include basic dotenv support in VSCode as a builtin extension.

title: remote-ssh configure root path for all install/download dirs
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently when you connect to a linux host via the ssh remote plugin.
It creates a downloads the needed files to three directories:

1. ~/.vscode
2. ~/.vscode-server
3. ~/..vscode-remote-containers

Currently only of these can be configured via the option `remote.SSH.serverInstallPath`.

The feature I'm requesting is to allow for a way to provide a different path instead of the home dir on remote options. Maybe something like `remote.SSH.rootInstallPath`. So the above 3 dirs would instead could be configured to be:

1. ~/.local/share/vscode/.vscode
2. ~/.local/share/vscode/.vscode-server
3. ~/.local/share/vscode/..vscode-remote-containers

This becomes useful in environments (ex corporate user servers) where home dirs are mounted NFS paths with small amount of disk. this feature would allow for me to provide paths to allocated disk for user scratch.

title: The content printed in the output panel was mistakenly printed into the editor
body:
Type: Bug When chatting with Copilot, sometimes my code files get unexpectedly corrupted because unexpected characters are inserted into the editor. For example, content that should have been in the output panel, or content that should have been in the Copilot chat window. However, I cannot fully reproduce this issue. Currently, I can only reliably reproduce the problem where content from the output panel gets printed into the editor by using the vicanent.gcmp plugin. But I believe this is not an issue with the vicanent.gcmp plugin itself, as this problem occasionally occurs even when the plugin is not installed—I just can't reproduce it consistently. Below are the reproduction steps: - Install the vicanent.gcmp plugin - Use an API key with no remaining balance - Send a message to the model provided by the vicanent.gcmp plugin - The vicanent.gcmp plugin will print error messages in the output panel, and then your current editor file will be corrupted I can also provide a reproduction video. title: Copilot “Manage Models...” option not shown when VSCode itself is using a `socks5h` proxy
body: Screenshot: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.372.0 - VS Code Version: 1.104.1 (Universal) - OS Version: macOS 26.0 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Model picker (`Manage Models...` option) - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): 3rd-party model via [extension that implemented `LanguageModelChatProvider` support](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=johnny-zhao.oai-compatible-copilot) - Logs: how can I get the log? Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set vscode's proxy setting to a valid socks5h proxy endpoint (e.g. `"http.proxy": "socks5h://127.0.0.1:8888"`) 2. Reload VSCode workspace 3. Open Copilot chat panel, wait for the model picker area to appear 4. See result: model picker appears, have a list of models but at the bottom of the list, there is no `Manage Models...` option. 5. Change the `http.proxy` setting value's protocol from `socks5h://` to `socks5://`, and then repeat step 2 and 3 6. See result: model picker appears, with `Manage Models...` option available at the end of the list. Additional info: 1. I am using Copilot Free, and intended to use 3rd-party API provider via the extension that mentioned above. 2. I *personally* think `Manage Models...` entry should always be available, especially when the user intentionally wants to use 3rd-party model provider instead of GitHub Copilot's first party models... Let me know if you need any additional information. Thanks!
